Description: Rim and body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Attic black-figured pottery type A cup; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed black below; exterior: top of rim black with dilute brown band just below; black-figure frieze consisting of procession of dancing satyrs and maenads to right, with grape clusters and vines in background; upper parts of four figures preserved, the satyrs with red on hair and beards, looking back and maenads wearing red fillets and chitons with faded white dots; white on faces and hands.
Producer name: Painted by: The Painter of Oxford 237
Curator's comments: The sherd belongs to the same vessel as British Museum 1888,0601.591. For parallels, see Oxford 237 (ABV, 643, no. 150).
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B601.29.1)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 449, no. B747)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0633) (Phase 1)
